statement.p: Suppose that as dry air rose its temperature dropped in a linear fashion. The temperature was measured at 1000 ft MSL as \displaystyle{22}^{\circ} C and at 2000 ft MSL as \displaystyle{24.1}^{\circ} C.
What is the rate of change of temperature with respect to altitude? Â
Your response may be as a fraction such as 2/1000 or decimal such as 0.002
What does this data imply about the temperature at 0 ft MSL?

solution.p: We want the ratio of temperature drop to altitude increase. \displaystyle\frac{{{24.1}-{22}}}{{{2000}-{1000}}}=-{0.0021}

Now that we know that ratio we can use a linear model to find the temperature at sea level. Because the temperature increases (we are going down not up) at a rate of -2.1 per 1000 ft the temperature will be expected to increase \displaystyle{1000}{\left(-\frac{{2.1}}{{1000}}\right)}=-{2.1}. That will result in a temperature of \displaystyle{22}\pm{2.1}={19.9}.
